what: Add or remove terms to a lmer formula string — add_term
title: Add or remove terms to a lmer formula string — add_term
text: Add remove terms lmer formula string

title: Add or remove terms to a lmer formula string — add_term
code: add_term(x, fixed = NULL, random = NULL, drop = NULL, drop.random = NULL, ...)

title: Add or remove terms to a lmer formula string — add_term
text: x Either mer formula object, string containing formula, lmer object. latter case, updated object returned instead new formula. fixed List character strings containing variable names terms include formula fixed terms. random List character strings containing variable names terms include formula random terms. drop List character strings containing variable names fixed terms exclude formula. drop.random List character strings containing variable names random terms exclude formula. ... Extra arguments passed `update`. Works `x` lmer object.

title: Add or remove terms to a lmer formula string — add_term
code: f1 <- "a ~ b + c + (1| group)" add_term(f1, , "Conservation") #> Loading required package: stringr #> Loading required package: lme4 #> Loading required package: Matrix #> [1] "a ~ b + c + (1+ Conservation | group) " add_term(f1, "Conservation*GDP") #> [1] "a ~ b + c + (1 | group) + Conservation*GDP" add_term(f1, "Conservation*GDP", "Conservation") #> [1] "a ~ b + c + (1+ Conservation | group) + Conservation*GDP"  add_term(f1, drop="female", drop.random = "g.agea") #> drop.random wasn't found in the formula #> [1] "a ~ b + c + ( 1 | group )"

title: Hoot's BRMSEA — brmsea
text: Adapted Hoots et al., 2017, https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/suppl/10.1177/0013164417709314

title: Hoot's BRMSEA — brmsea
code: brmsea(   file = "bayesian.gh5",   file_sel = "Chi-square values",   ms = TRUE,   cil = 0.05,   ciu = 0.95,   allout = FALSE,   Min1 = TRUE,   Ngr = 4 )

title: Hoot's BRMSEA — brmsea
text: file gh5 file Mplus file_sel Character. name predictive check used. Default "Chi-square values". ms Logical. TRUE, model mean structure model. Default TRUE. cil Lower bound posterior probability interval. Default .05 ciu Upper bound posterior probability interval. Default .95 allout Logical. TRUE, returns BRMSEA values instead posterior probability interval. Default FALSE. Min1 Logical. TRUE, uses N-1 denominator. Default TRUE. Ngr Number groups model. Default 4.

title: Correlation table with stars — cor_table
text: Produces data frame correlations stars standing significance Create Correlation Table Significance Stars Creates formatted correlation matrix optional significance stars. Handles tibble inputs provides flexible output formats.

title: Correlation table with stars — cor_table
code: cor_table(d, method = "spearman", star = TRUE, raw = FALSE)

title: Correlation table with stars — cor_table
text: d data frame tibble containing numeric variables method Character string indicating correlation method. One "pearson", "kendall", "spearman" (default) star Logical. TRUE (default), adds significance stars correlations raw Logical. TRUE, returns raw correlation matrix without formatting

title: Correlation table with stars — cor_table
text: matrix containing formatted correlations significance stars (requested)   raw correlation values

title: Correlation table with stars — cor_table
text: Significance levels: * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001

title: Correlation table with stars — cor_table
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- data.frame(x = rnorm(100), y = rnorm(100), z = rnorm(100)) cor_table(data)                          # With stars cor_table(data, star = FALSE)           # Without stars cor_table(data, raw = TRUE)             # Raw correlations cor_table(data, method = "pearson")     # Pearson method } # }

what: Shows data.frame or model(s) in RStudio viewer — df_to_viewer

text: via stargazer knitr

title: Shows data.frame or model(s) in RStudio viewer — df_to_viewer
code: df_to_viewer(   x,   rownames = TRUE,   summ = F,   kable = TRUE,   by = NULL,   html = FALSE,   colformat = NULL,   sg.style = "ajs",   k.style = "default",   digits = 2,   kable.options = list(),   cells.by.merge = T,   cells.by.indent = T,   ... )

title: Shows data.frame or model(s) in RStudio viewer — df_to_viewer
text: rownames Logical, rownames shown. summ Passed `summary` argument stargazer. kable logical. data.frame passed kable.  true, ... passed function kableExtra::kable_styling. Defaults TRUE. FALSE, passes df stargazer. name variable group rows . Used `kable=TRUE` html viewer ignored just html code returned (useful embed Rmarkdown outputs colformat Formats column using `sprintf`. numeric, applies rounding , character, passed `sprintf` directly. Can named match x's column names. named, must length columns x. sg.style 'style' argument `stargazer`. k.style Applies custom kableStyling style, might take two values "default", "custom". kable.options list arguments passed `kable` function. cells..merge headers created `` argument can single cell spanning columns (TRUE) subheader can put new line's first column (FALSE). latter tables easier hande , e.g. MS Word. cells..indent Logical. Whether '' headers indent. ... arguments passed `stargazer` `kableStyling()`. df data.frame show. Also works list fitted models supported .

title: Various versions of PSR — each_param_psr_mplus
text: Returns vector different versions PSR: "Rstan" --date, provided  Rhat function (Vehtari et al., 2019). "Gelman" (Gelman et al. (2004)). "Mplus" (Asparouhov  Muthen, 2010), "Naive" raw ratio sum - within-chain variances within-chain variance.

what: Make a quick network graph — get_net
title: Make a quick network graph — get_net
text: Make quick network graph

title: Make a quick network graph — get_net
code: get_net(   df = NULL,   cv = NULL,   n = NULL,   title = "",   legend = "none",   gamma = 0.3,   layout = "fr",   start = "glasso",   stepwise = T,   seed = 1,   group.id = NA,   item_label = function(x) gsub("\\D", "", x),   return.df = F,   ... )

title: Make a quick network graph — get_net
text: df Data frame cv Correlation matrix (df NULL) title Title plot legend Legend position gamma Gamma parameter model selection function, see `ggmModSelect` layout Default "fr". Network layout. See `ggraph::ggraph` start Default "glasso", see `ggmModSelect` stepwise Default TRUE, see `ggmModSelect` seed Attempt make plots replicable. group.id Vector regex expressions apply variable names use group variables. item_label Function converts item names node labels. return.df Logical, true, returns tidygraph dataset instead plot.

title: Make a quick network graph — get_net
code: data("HolzingerSwineford1939", package = "lavaan") get_net(HolzingerSwineford1939[, 7:15],        group.id = c(first.factor = "1|2|3",                     second = "4|5|6",                     third = "7|8|9"),        legend = "bottom" ) #> Loading required package: qgraph #> Warning: there is no package called ‘qgraph’ #> Loading required package: tidygraph #> Warning: there is no package called ‘tidygraph’ #> Loading required package: ggraph #> Warning: there is no package called ‘ggraph’ #> Error in ggmModSelect(cv, n = n, stepwise = stepwise, gamma = gamma, start = start,     nCores = 6, ...): could not find function "ggmModSelect"

what: Convert lavaan to draw.io diagram — lav_to_draw
title: Convert lavaan to draw.io diagram — lav_to_draw
text: Experimental. Produces  SEM diagrams can manually edited draw.io environment. pain work "static" images semPlot similar packages. often give make using MS POwerpoint similar software... Now can just run function using fitted lavaan model (simply syntax model - useful representing theoretical models) paste code draw.io. result automatic layour likely still  messy, least now can arrange variables arrows manually power draw.io – achieve desired result seconds. See details specific instructions.

title: Convert lavaan to draw.io diagram — lav_to_draw
code: lav_to_draw(   m,   layout = "horizontaltree",   item.labels = NULL,   std = T,   elements = NULL,   thickness = 1,   clip = T )

title: Convert lavaan to draw.io diagram — lav_to_draw
text: m character, following lavaan syntax model conventions (see examples), fitted lavaan object. layout Format output.  Possible values  'verticaltree', 'horizontaltree', 'verticalflow', 'horizontalflow', 'organic', 'circle', 'orgchart', 'auto', 'none', JSON string used draw.io -> Layout -> Apply. Default 'horizontaltree' item.labels Named vector names item/variable names values labels. Adds custom labels. std Whether include standardized unstandardized estimates. elements Feature development. Character vector. include diagram, possible values "obs", "lat.covs", "resid.covs", "resid", "slopes", "intercepts/thresholds" (currently supported). thickness line width multiplier: paths made proportional coefficients model, sometimes parameters small line (.e.g, .5 mean half pixel). Use higher numbers make paths visible.

title: Convert lavaan to draw.io diagram — lav_to_draw
text: Produces csv-like code pasted draw.io cool thing can manually adjust result –  feature unavailable known diagram producers lavaan far. Step 1.  Run function using either fitted lavaan model syntax. Step 2. function produce code (also copied clipboard automatically). Step 3. Go draw.io (either website desktop version), Arrange -> Insert - Advanced - CSV... insert code window. Step 4. diagram already can start editing line goals. Probably first thing try different layouts - can apply Arrange -> Layout -> choose one .

what: Create a Graphviz path diagram using lavaan syntax — lav_to_graph
title: Create a Graphviz path diagram using lavaan syntax — lav_to_graph
text: Converts lavaan syntax object graphviz code. Requires 'DiagrammeR' package.

title: Create a Graphviz path diagram using lavaan syntax — lav_to_graph
code: lav_to_graph(   m,   layout = "dot",   adds = NULL,   file = NA,   rmarkdown = FALSE,   code.only = F,   try.labels = T,   label.wrap = 15,   std = F,   elements = c("obs", "lat.covs", "resid.covs", "resid", "slopes"),   ... )

title: Create a Graphviz path diagram using lavaan syntax — lav_to_graph
text: m character, following lavaan syntax model conventions (see examples), fitted lavaan object. layout Can 'dot', 'neato', 'twopi', 'circo', 'fdp' adds graphviz code added graph. file character, file name save svg code, usually 'svg' extension. rmarkdown Logical. function used context Rmarkdown. try.labels Try extracting labels data. label.wrap Number character wrap label std Whether include standardized unstandardized estimates. elements Character vector. include diagram, possible values "obs", "lat.covs", "resid.covs", "resid", "slopes", "intercepts/thresholds" (currently supported). ... arguments passed DiagrammeR::grViz function.

title: Create a Graphviz path diagram using lavaan syntax — lav_to_graph
text: function invisibly returns dot code can edited make customized diagrams. can use package DiagrammeR graphviz engine, e.g. http://graphviz.. likely useful large complex models.

title: Create a Graphviz path diagram using lavaan syntax — lav_to_graph
code: lav_to_graph("F =~ a1 + a2 + a3 + a4") #> Error in lavaanify(m): could not find function "lavaanify" lav_to_graph("F =~ a1 + a2 + a3 + a4; a1 ~~ a2; d ~ F ", engine = "neato") #> Error in lavaanify(m): could not find function "lavaanify"

what: Create Regression Table for Multilevel Models — lmer_table
title: Create Regression Table for Multilevel Models — lmer_table
text: Produces formatted table multiple lmer fitted objects various fit statistics model comparisons.

title: Create Regression Table for Multilevel Models — lmer_table
code: lmer_table(   models,   fit_stats = c("fit", "random"),   model_names = NULL,   show_viewer = TRUE,   silent = TRUE,   digits = 2,   ... )

title: Create Regression Table for Multilevel Models — lmer_table
text: models List fitted lmer objects fit_stats Character vector statistics include. Options: "ICC", "VIF", "REML", "fit", "LRT", "random", "random_p", "random_ci", "random_anova", "R2". See details. model_names Character vector model names (default: auto-generated) show_viewer Logical. Show RStudio viewer (TRUE) go stargazer's default (latex, see `type` argument stargazer silent Logical. Suppress progress messages digits Integer. Number digits rounding ... Additional arguments passed stargazer

title: Create Regression Table for Multilevel Models — lmer_table
text: Invisibly returns HTML output path

title: Create Regression Table for Multilevel Models — lmer_table
text: Fit statistics: fit Deviance, AIC, BIC, parameters, groups, observations, convergence ICC Intra-class correlation coefficient R2 R-squared empty model comparison LRT Likelihood ratio tests nested models random Random effect variances random_p Random effect variances bootstrapped significance sign random_ci Random effect variances bootstrapped confidence intervals sig sign VIF Maximum variance inflation factor REML Whether REML estimation used

title: Create Regression Table for Multilevel Models — lmer_table
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data("sleepstudy", package = "lme4") m1 <- lmer(Reaction ~ Days + (1|Subject), sleepstudy) m2 <- lmer(Reaction ~ Days + (1+Days|Subject), sleepstudy) lmer_table(list(m1, m2)) } # }

title: manipulate mplus file — manipulate_mplus

title: manipulate mplus file — manipulate_mplus
code: manipulate_mplus(inp, target, replacement, run = T, read = T, keep.files = T)

title: manipulate mplus file — manipulate_mplus
text: inp Input file path. target Character. Block Mplus code replace. replacement Character. Mplus code replace target. Can vector - case, multiple outputs created. run Whether new input files executed.  FALSE, returns vector paths new input files. read Logical, whether read models . FALSE, returns list paths output files. keep.files Logical. Whether input output files shuld kept disk. FALSE, Mplus files deleted read wish readModels.

title: manipulate mplus file — manipulate_mplus
text: Sorted data frame differing n factors level fit statistics. default extracts CFI, RMSEA, RMSEA.CI.LO, RMSEA.CI.HI, SRMR.w, SRMR.b, SABIC, AIC, Chi.sq, Chi.df, Chi.p, Chi.scale.

what: Combine Named Vectors into Data Frame by Matching Names — match_named_vectors
title: Combine Named Vectors into Data Frame by Matching Names — match_named_vectors
text: Creates data frame matching names across multiple vectors. Unnamed elements (NA names) preserved separate rows vector.

title: Combine Named Vectors into Data Frame by Matching Names — match_named_vectors
code: match_named_vectors(...)

title: Combine Named Vectors into Data Frame by Matching Names — match_named_vectors
text: ... Named vectors, single list named vectors

title: Combine Named Vectors into Data Frame by Matching Names — match_named_vectors
text: Data frame matched names rows vectors columns

title: Combine Named Vectors into Data Frame by Matching Names — match_named_vectors
text: Named elements matched name across vectors. Unnamed elements   (NA names) added separate rows, identified vector source.   Column names taken argument names generated V1, V2, etc.

title: Combine Named Vectors into Data Frame by Matching Names — match_named_vectors
code: v1 <- c(a = 1, b = 2, 3)        # 3 has no name v2 <- c(a = 10, c = 30, 40)     # 40 has no name v3 <- c(b = 200, d = 400, 500)  # 500 has no name match_named_vectors(v1, v2, v3) #>   V1 V2  V3 #> a  1 10  NA #> b  2 NA 200 #>    3 40 500 #> c NA 30  NA #> d NA NA 400  # With custom names match_named_vectors(first = v1, second = v2, third = v3) #>   first second third #> a     1     10    NA #> b     2     NA   200 #>       3     40   500 #> c    NA     30    NA #> d    NA     NA   400  # With a list match_named_vectors(list(v1 = v1, v2 = v2, v3 = v3)) #>   v1 v2  v3 #> a  1 10  NA #> b  2 NA 200 #>    3 40 500 #> c NA 30  NA #> d NA NA 400

what: Plot cross-level interactions for mer objects — random_interaction

text: Takes object produced lme4::lmer() function, returns interaction plot(s).

title: Plot cross-level interactions for mer objects — random_interaction
code: random_interaction(   x,   real = TRUE,   z.levels = c("1SD", "2SD", "1.2SD", "all"),   scatter = FALSE,   labs = NULL,   x.levels = NULL,   silent = T,   ... )

title: Plot cross-level interactions for mer objects — random_interaction
text: x mer object produced lmer function real Logical. Whether real groups used predict random effects, extrapolate using means standard deviations? z.levels String, indicating levels moderating group-level variable computed. Can take () following values: "1SD". Default. Computes group-level mean standard deviation moderating variable finds groups similar values, prediction slopes values made based three real  groups. "1SD" Computes group-level mean standard deviation moderating variable. "2SD" Computes group-level mean doubled standard deviation moderating variable. "12SD" Computes group-level mean plots standard deviation doubled standard deviation moderating variable. scatter Logical. scatterplot created addition? labs List arguments passed +labs() PLUS elements named  "line1", "line2"... used name lines plot. less "line" elements lines plot, ignored. x.levels desired x-axis coordinates, individual-level term. NULL (default) defined automatically. ... Arguments passed effect function effects package.

title: Plot cross-level interactions for mer objects — random_interaction
text: Returns one several ggplots. case one plot returned can appended +theme(), +geom_(), etc.

title: Plot cross-level interactions for mer objects — random_interaction
text: somehow repeats functionality 'sjPlot::sjp.int', differs able select real groups close +/- 1 sd mean moderating variable; makes prettier customizable plots.

what: Extract and export Mplus trace and autocorrelation plots into pdf — traceplots_mplus
title: Extract and export Mplus trace and autocorrelation plots into pdf — traceplots_mplus
text: function exports available plots parameter every chain. Therefore can take long time resulting pdf file can large. page pdf specific parameter.

title: Extract and export Mplus trace and autocorrelation plots into pdf — traceplots_mplus
code: traceplots_mplus(   x,   is.file = F,   pdffile = NULL,   gg = T,   param.id = NULL,   raster = F,   niter = NULL,   chains = NULL,   PSR = TRUE,   PSR.version = "Rstan",   ESS = T )

title: Extract and export Mplus trace and autocorrelation plots into pdf — traceplots_mplus
text: x Either model read readModels, gh5 file produced Mplus (Mplus stated PLOTS: TYPE PLOT2;) .file Logical, x argument file name. Default FALSE, (.e. R object, model read readModels) pdffile File name pdf report export plots. Defaults x argument  '.pdf' extension .file == TRUE, extracts original filename file x readModels object. gg Logical. Whether ggplot  base R graphics used. Default ggplot slower flexible, e.g. many chains. param.id Single interger vector. Single intterger shows 1:param.id  parameters plot, vector shows parameters order id. NULL (default), parameters used. raster Logical. Currently used. option convert vector plots raster plots save space produce smaller pdfs. Currently used. niter many iterations shown traceplot. NULL (default) refers iterations.  However, traceplots long chains may result highly overplotted graphics slow take lot space disk. specified number take random sample values iterations. PSR Whether PSR (R-hat) printed parameter. See each_param_psr_mplus. PSR.version Version PSR; default "Rstan" - --date, provided Rstan::Rhat function (Vehtari et al., 2019). possible values: "Gelman" (Gelman et al. (2004)); "Mplus" (Asparouhov  Muthen, 2010), "Naive" raw ratio sum - within-chain variances within-chain variance. ESS Logical. Whether effective sample size printed plots. See ess_bulk

title: Extract and export Mplus trace and autocorrelation plots into pdf — traceplots_mplus
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ m <- MplusAutomation::readModels("mybayes.out") convergencePlotsMplus(m, niter = 5000, PSR.version = "Mplus")  # or directly from gh5 file: convergencePlotsMplus("mybayes.gh5", param.id = 1, PSR.version = "Rstan", gg=F) } # }
